div.p:
I thank you for
the note about the
"Field" effusion - &
send you an order
for certain paintings
by Baines our
artist for a while
on the Zambesi.
I applied for them
to Lord Russell
He said that the artist Baines having
been paid they were
public property - &
when I told him that
I meant only to use
them for my forth-
coming work he
sent this order.
Tthey are to be returned
to the Foreign Office
when you are done
with them - so you
had better, please,
get them and if
they are to your
mind employ one
to reduce what you
like - Poor Captain
Need gets on very
slowly in consequence
of his infirmities.
He is a confirmed
invalid - very
glad of the work
but sorely tried with
stomach spine &c.
He has composed
two which I think
will do.

Soapy got me sorely
against my will to a
meeting at NotinghamNottingham
yesterday. I told him
privately how ill bishop
Mackenzie had been
sustained - his associates
being utterly unfit to be
missionaries - and he
knew a little already.
Tthis is the chief thing
I mean to do in the
matter - praise bishop
Mackenzie & let the
rest drop in the book.
Baines & Chapman were
together latterly I am going
to look through Baines
immediately - I know
nothing of the publisher
of Chapman. David Livingstone
